title.narrative: OUTPUT 1: DELIVER, MONITOR AND EVALUATEMULTISECTOR PLANS

description.narrative: By end 2022, stakeholders have increased capacity to plan, coordinate and advocate successfully for adequate and predictable funding, to enable quality, multi-sectoral nutrition services., which contributes to Adolescent Health And Nutrition, Early Childhood Development, Prevention Of Stunting And Other Forms Of Malnutrition, Treatment Of Severe Acute Malnutrition. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Advocacy And Public Engagement, Developing And Leveraging Resources And Partnerships, Evaluations, Research And Data, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building, United Nations Working Together. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: By 2022, the most vulnerable boys and girls, as well as pregnant and breastfeeding women, through improved utilization of services and improved practices show a measurable reduction in stunting and wasting.

sector.narrative: National multisectoral strategies and plans to prevent stunting (excludes intervention-specific strategies)

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: By end 2022, stakeholders have increased capacity to plan, coordinate and advocate successfully for adequate and predictable funding, to enable quality, multi-sectoral nutrition services.

description.narrative: The establishment of the Pakistan National Nutrition Coordination Council, chaired by the Prime Minister, revision of the national framework for stunting reduction and provincial multisectoral strategies and action plans and development of U$3.2 billion nutrition-specific development budget (PC-1) informed by the findings from the National Nutrition Survey conducted with UNICEF support, has reshaped the nutrition landscape in Pakistan. Public finance tracking support to Scaling Up Nutrition units resulted in the provincial public allocation for nutrition (US$3 million in Punjab and US$8.4 million in KP). 3,563 health practitioners were trained on the Breastmilk Substitutes Code to promote breastfeeding in health facilities | Status:On-track | As-of Date:31/12/2019

title.narrative: Existence of an emergency preparedness plan for nutrition
Existence of a functional national multisectoral committee for nutrition
Adoption of the International Code on Marketing of Breastmilk substitutes as legislation and subsequent relevant World Health Assembly resolutions

baseline.value: Breastfeeding law was promulgated in 2002 and in 2009, rules and regulations were developed at the federal level. All four provinces adopted the law and amendments were made according to provincial context.

target.value: 2022:Four provinces to formulate and approve BMS Rules. Two regions to promulgate BMS Law and formulate and approve BMS Rules.

actual.value:
2019:Legislation approved in 1 province, vetted by law department in 1 province, in final draft in 1 province and at federal level, drafted in 2 provinces/ regions
Emphasis shifted to updating and implementing BMS legislation mainly first ACT and then RULES, following WHA,2016 resolution
